erikkwakkel:

Thirsty dog

You are looking at the last page of a late-14th-century scientific book made in England. When the scribe finished copying the last text, a treatise on measuring, half of the page was still blank. The temptation to draw a funny picture in that empty space was just too tempting. And so he drew a knight with a big sword tapping wine from a big casket. Standing on the basement stairs he fills an enormous jug. His dog is equally thirsty and licks the drops that are spilling from the tap. What an odd scene in such a serious book. But also: what a great thing to encounter as a reader who worked his way through complex mathematical texts - including Euclidâs Elementa. âI finished it,“ you can hear him think, ânow a drink!” Cheers.

Pic: Columbia University, Plimpton MS 160 (England, late 14th century). More about this manuscript here.
